ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned the fundamental developmental psych findings, but mostly learned how to critically think about psychology and to devise our own experiment!
I got better at group work and public speaking
Overall this course is more about presenting than learning about developmental psychology. I just thought the formatting could have been better geared towards the material than group projects.
I learned a lot about babies and young children, especially that they are capable of a lot more than we think! I also learned more about methods to test these subjects of study.
I learned more about how children develop in various domains, and how to craft a psych study.

I received depth on many topics that had been introduced to me in introduction to psychology. I found concepts incredibly interesting. I also have a great grasp on how to write a quality scientific research paper.
The technicalities of writing research papers was the primary skill I took away with this class. In addition, presenting in front of large groups of people.
I learned about how babies are smarter than we think
This course taught me how to read psychology papers more effectively. The assignments and work done outside of class was where I learned the most.
I gained a lot of knowledge about how the human mind develops in early life, the capacities that babies and young children have, and what makes humans unique.

This course offers a broad introduction to developmental psychology, both to the theory and how this theory is founded through research. It also teaches you how to interpret, critique, and come up with empirical research paradigms.
Learnt about many aspects of child development
I learned a lot! Not only about child development, but about how to give a good presentation and work with a group.
I learned how to conduct literature searches, formulate research questions, and write research papers.
How to write a developmental psychology research paper, topics in developmental psychology
Basic principles and studies of developmental psychology.
Lovely professor and I highly recommend this course
Great foundation into different areas of developmental psychology. If there's something specific you're interested, it was probably covered at some point.

learned more about how to characterize the cognitive abilities of children at different stages of development, can apply what I learned to productive interactions with children, gained increased presentation and groupwork skills
I learned a lot about children's minds and how we all develop.
foundational knowledge on development as well as how to write a research paper on a developmental topic

I learend how to read and comprehend psychology papers and other research. I also learned how childrne preform over their development and why humans are the way they are. I bettered my public speaking and was able to engage with classmates.
Gained many skills about developmental psychology and learned a lot about how best to interact with children and when they gain certain skills.

I learned a lot about the development of young children and the psychology behind that development. I also improved at making presentations and public speaking, debating, and writing professional research papers.
Grew my knowledge of developmental psychology and different methodologies
I learned some of the key principles of development psychology and learned about how developmental psychology research is conducted.
basic theories and concepts in developmental psych
An overview of topics, debates, and findings in developmental psychology
basic introduction to developmental psychology
Survey course of dev psych concepts.
This course taught me to learn differently and allowed the space to explore which topics I was interested in.

This course taught me how to better read academic papers, design psychological experiments, different big questions about children's development and methods on how to explore those questions. We spent time on topic like personality, motivation, cognitive abilities, and intelligence and talking about the ongoing research and debate within these topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: promoted critical thinking and the final project allows you to learn a lot but is broken up into very manageable chunks
Weaknesses: Prof Leonard is an amazing teacher and I think she has learned a lot from her first semester of teaching here. Lectures were engaging, but we did a lot of student presentations which were not

On the one hand I think the group work and projects were fine, it they were only done once in a while. But a huge weakness of the course is that there was no real exams, just one final paper and then a lot of group work. I did not feel like the group work was designed in a way that taught me anything. Sure, we got better at public speaking, but I took this class to learn about Dev psych. I feel like I'm walking away knowing the few studies that I did my group work on really well, but nothing much other than that.

i appreciated that there were no tests in the class, it allowed us to engage with the material just for learning without pressure. I also found a lot of the projects to be quite engaging but a weakness was the amount of in class group projects and presentations.

If you want to learn how to present scientific information, this course is for you. I really did not learn much about developmental psychology and you can get away with not paying attention to anything in class as it can all be done outside of class on your own.

I wish there were more lectures done by the professor over group projects and presentation of the group projects. I tended to learn and take away a lot more when the professor was lecturing. This is not to say the group projects were not engaging, I just wished there were less of them.

A lot of professors say they don't believe that tests should define our grade and how we do in a class but don't actually put that in action. I think this was a great class where the professor actually attempted to teach without testing. I learned a lot without all the added stress especially as someone who isn't a great test taker but is willing to put in the effort.

Strengths: Professor Leonard is a wonderful lecturer, and this is a fascinating topic! Weaknesses: Only that Prof. Leonard didn't spend enough time lecturing! Instead, a lot of class time was spent with students giving presentations. It would have been great to have more time with Professor Leonard sharing her knowledge and insights on these topics. I also think that more frequent, smaller assignments would have been more effective for my learning than a few very large assignments.

Since it was a shift in professors I understand that there will be course difficulties. With that being said, the group projects were not a good way to grade. I was placed into a group where minimal work was done and due to this, I received a grade I did not deserve.

I went into the course with the impression that it would be a standard lecture course. I was surprised to find that there was a very high amount of group projects and presentations. I think the group project and student-presenting format was hindering to my learning. It was hard to follow student presentations, as they were all formatted differently and it seemed somewhat disorganized.

Strengths: no exams, creative assignments to engage with the material 
Weaknesses: difficult to actually retain knowledge because there were no exams
Weakness: We could have had more guidance with the final paper.

One major strength of the course was the nature of the assignments - they were diverse and provided enough direction to allow for student creativity. The biggest weakness of the course was the lectures themselves. There were no quizzes and the assignments didn't really line up with the content of the lectures so there really wasn't any incentive to pay attention in class. The lectures did feel like a bit of a waste of time.

For me, the lectures were the main strength of this course. Prof. Leonard is a wonderful lecturer -- it's clear how much she is excited about the content, and that makes lectures really engaging. She was also really responsive and easy to meet with. There were no tests in this course and I was still really engaged during each lecture because I found the content to be so interesting. We had several group presentations assigned, and, for me, this was a weakness. I think too much class time was spent on students presenting to one another, when we would have actually learned more from Prof. Leonard herself. A couple notes, though: 1) I don't like group presentations in general and have friends in the course who enjoyed this aspect, and 2) this was Prof. Leonard's first time teaching the course and she continuously mentioned that she is incorporating our feedback for the future, so I imagine this will change to some extent.
A lot of busy work.
I would have liked to have more personal feedback on my assignments.
Not having any exams made the class a lot more enjoyable. Really good class and lectures were presented well and were engaging.

Strengths: lively professor and interesting content
Weaknesses: a lot of a group projects
Amazing Professor!  Great class, really centered around learning and engagement.
The course was not very focused on grades and traditional assessments which was refreshing.

Strengths: very interesting topics were covered in class
Weaknesses: too many group projects slowed down our intake of more interesting topics that could be covered

The course started out a bit disorganized and rocky since this is her first time teaching at Yale. However, Professor Leonard cared a lot about improving, and by the middle/end it was so fun and enjoyable. The assignments at the beginning were a bit unhelpful in terms of the content, particularly since she divided the huge lecture class into groups of 4-5 or so to individually present to the rest of class, which took up a lot of time and no one was really paying attention. But by the end, the content and assignments shifted towards more engaging work and lectures and was super interesting.

Strengths -- high energy professor, great use of videos in slides. Weaknesses -- way too much group project-based learning. Since all assessments of the course were based on projects, I felt little motivation to keep tabs on how much material I was retaining on all of the content learned.
no more debates!

Developmental debates (on controversial topics in devpsych) were fun and engaging. Papers were enjoyably loosely defined so we could write about whatever interested us most. The reverse inference challenge didn't really work, but did teach us lots about our topic.

Strengths:
- got to engage with a lot of different students
- academic freedom to choose to work with topics that interest you
- lots of real-world application from both information and types of assignments
- lots of feedback from instructors

Weaknesses:
- group presentations took up a lot of class time, and lecture sometimes felt rushed
- though amended to be more forgiving, having graded lecture participation during COVID was a bit concerning given the considerable amount of contact tracing/development of COVID-like symptoms from colds etc. that would hopefully prevent people from going to in-person class
Interesting content and good lectures, however not super intellectually challenging.

strengths: the professor! she clearly loves the material and her lectures were engaging and easy to learn from
weaknesses: none!
Great structure, great varied assessments, great teaching team that was engaged and cared and made time if you asked.

One strength was availability of resources (from both professor Leonard and both TFs). I found it very easy to communciate with all of them and they akways gave very constructive feedback. 

One weakness was some of the structure. I almost wished the three debates were back to back, to keep students engaged and so that the workload of the course was even throughout the semester. I know some people that debated early and got it out of the way vs other students that debated during the last week of classes which was stressful.

Strengths - lots o opportunities for engagement 
Weaknesses - some group activities should potentially be edited for maximum engagement
Too many presentations for a lecture. Two presentations should be the maximum. Also, a lot of what we were learning in class as far as content was not needed in our work for the class.

There were too many projects and presentations that it was difficult to keep track of everything. The lectures by Prof. Leonard were really interesting and most helpful to my learning. I wish that fewer of the lectures had gone towards group presentations. The final paper was a little bit strange to write since we had to make up results, but overall I learned a lot from the assignment. I am torn about whether a final exam would be beneficial. Perhaps having the first half of the semester organized around lectures and a midterm exam would make sense so we have a really strong foundation, and then the second half of the semester could be more project oriented and allow us to focus on our areas of interest.

The course primarily revolved around group projects and presentations -- getting through all the class presentations took a really long time, and students were often made to rush through presentations that they'd spent a long time preparing. The lectures were really interesting, but because of how many days were spent on projects / presentations, there weren't actually that many lectures and they felt kind of disjointed.
many group presentations that were not always effective to learn from (but will be adjusted!

Strengths: low workload, interesting content, no exams
Weaknesses: the pollEvs. I definitely understand having some sort of lecture quizzes to encourage attendance, but poll ev just had a lot of issues

strengths - engaging lectures
weaknesses - sometimes the class material and assignments weren't conducive for learning

Rather shallow and a bit slow on the progression of concepts that we learned. Far too many group projects and days when i completely checked out in class because entire sessions spent on group presentations of research papers or debates - this didn't feel like a good use of anyone's time. 
Overall good energy from prof and TFs with great presentations and engaging videos to illustrate concepts.
I really enjoyed lecture and appreciated the interactive nature of the course but do wish it was slightly more lecture-based.
The strengths were the uniqueness of the class and the way Professor Leonard was able to make a lecture class feel engaging and close.

Strengths: Professor is very invested in teaching, not just memorization like the old model of the class 
Weaknesses: Too many student presentations
I think this class could have use more interactive components to be more engaging but I think the structure of the lectures functioned well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Leonard is amazing and I'm sure she'll get even better the more she teaches. Take this course if you'd like to learn for the sake of learning and engage with the material in a way that is different from other classes. The public information project and the final research paper are essential elements of the course that make you think, but are super manageable and divided into chunks that make it so they do not feel to challenging. Show up to class! Prof leonard does really care about whether you are there and if you are learning.
Not really if it is taught in the same way. Like I said I think it could be taught much much better and more organized.
I think the course was overall okay. It wasn't the worst course I have taken, but think there are better psychology courses out there that are more engaging.

Yes! Children and babies are fascinating and trying to figure out how to test what they know takes a lot of creativity that we learn about in class.  However, this is an extremely introductory course, one of the projects was actually able reading research papers. As an upperclassmen, assignments like this were less engaging than compared to the in class debates that we had.

Yes, if you are interested in this subject! It may be possible to coast through this class with relatively little engagement, which it seems like many students did, but if you want to get more out of it, Professor Leonard and the TAs are great resources and you should go speak with them!
No, unless you need to take it for major requirements.
Yeah. If you're interested in psychology. It is possible to learn something valuable from this course but the assignments take up a good chunk of time and attending the lectures can be droning.

Yes! I loved this course. I found all of the content super interesting (there is a good amount of overlap with what you would learn in an intro psych or cogsci class but I learned a lot). Prof. Leonard is a great and engaging lecturer, and it's clear how much she likes the material she teaches. There are definitely things I would change about it (I think we spent too much time on group presentations and should have had more lectures from Prof. Leonard) but this was her first time teaching the course and I think it will only improve in the future. Also, there were no exams, which meant that you get out of it what you put in. I loved lectures and paid attention during them so I felt like I learned a lot, but it was definitely possible to zone out and not walk away with much from the course.
Yes, it was interesting and helped me with public speaking (we did a lot of projects that required speaking in front of the whole lecture)
I would recommend this course to any student that is interested. It gives you a good understanding of how we learned the things that seem so normal as an adult.
Yes I would recommend. Very interesting and fun class. The class format is a nice change from usual classes
I would, it's a good way to learn about child development without being overwhelmed with the workload and field
yes! Professor Leonard is amazing, you learn a lot and the course is actually fun!
Yes, I think the course helped me learn in less conventional ways through presentations and projects rather than traditional testing.
Yes, developmental psychology was more interesting than I expected thanks to the professor! :)
Absolutely! You learn so much about children, the developmental process and human nature in general, its remarkable.
Not unless it is a requirement.
YEs!!!!
Yes! Fun, interesting course with lots of group work. There weren't any exams so the impetus was much more on us to learn, rather than religiously study every detail.
probably; lots of small group projects/deadlines but interesting subject matter ad engaging lectures
Yes.
absolutely recommend - the class is fun and I learned a lot
Yes
Definitely- I think the topic was super interesting. Who doesn't love learning about kids and how smart they actually are!
Yes!
Absolutely. Professor Leonard is an excellent teacher.
Yes, if they are a psychology major or any major that is heavy on research papers.
yess if you want to learn more about babies and how people grow and change over time
Yes! It's fun and interesting, and Prof Leonard is great! She tried out lots of different projects and learning styles- I thunk this class will get better and better over time.

Yes! Super interesting and I think its really important to know about development. It was different from other classes Ive taken because it encouraged lots of group work and projects. I would def classify this as a gut
i would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in learning more about developmental psychology
This was the first time teaching it, i would recommend prof leonard, but i assume the structure of the course will be different next time it is taught.
Of course! I would recommend this course to anyone interested in developmental psychology.
Definitely! A must take class

I would recommend this class to early psychology students who have an interest in children's development. I think thee class had a lot of interesting and engaging information and surveys a variety of topics so you can find what you are more interested in further researching. If someone is looking for a more hands on class tho I wouldn't recommend this course.
